title: 112_hr3139
content: The Act may be cited as the "District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act". It establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds. The "District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act" establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds. It includes provisions for qualified contributions to a natural disaster protection fund and a special rule for assets held in the fund for determining gross income. The "District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act" establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds. Distributions from a natural disaster protection fund are subject to specific rules, including the exclusion of certain distributions from gross income. The "District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act" establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds, which are defined as money, securities, or property held by a qualified insurance company in a segregated account designated as a 'natural disaster protection fund'. The "District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act" requires a qualified insurance company to hold a 'natural disaster protection fund' in a licensed bank in the District of Columbia. The fund must be invested according to investment laws in the District of Columbia, and any excess balance must be distributed to the company by the following taxable year. The "District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act" mandates that a qualified insurance company must maintain a 'natural disaster protection fund' in a District of Columbia bank. The fund must comply with investment laws and any surplus must be distributed by the next taxable year. A qualified insurance company is defined as an insurer or reinsurer incorporated in the District of Columbia, supervised by the District's Commissioner of Insurance, and with an office employing at least 10 full-time equivalent employees, including 5 in the District. A qualified insurance company must maintain a 'natural disaster protection fund' in a District of Columbia bank. The company must comply with investment laws, have at least 10 full-time equivalent employees, including 5 in the District, and be subject to various taxes and fees imposed by the District of Columbia. Additionally, the company is subject to an additional tax on premiums charged for natural catastrophic risk coverage written through the fund, at a rate determined by the District of Columbia. The term 'qualified contribution' refers to a contribution made by a qualified insurance company to a fund established for covering qualified losses, limited to the total of net premiums received during a taxable year. The contribution should not exceed the amount reasonably at risk for the payment of qualified losses insured through the fund, less reinsurance. The term 'qualified distribution' refers to payments made for qualified losses under insurance or reinsurance contracts, spreading catastrophe risk, excess balance drawdown, fund maintenance expenses, and claims investigation. The term 'qualified loss' refers to insured losses on a United States risk caused by events such as wind, earthquake, flood, tsunami, volcanic eruption, fire, hail, snow, ice, or other winter catastrophes. The text discusses criteria for a catastrophe designation or minimum aggregate insured loss, which includes total insured losses exceeding $1 billion industry-wide, a disaster declaration by the President, or a state of emergency declared by a Governor or chief executive. The Governor or chief executive of a State, possession, or territory of the United States declares a disaster or state of emergency. The Property Claims Services unit of Insurance Services Office, Inc., declares a catastrophic industry-wide loss. The term 'excess balance drawdown amount' refers to the fund balance exceeding the total exposure to qualified losses at the end of the taxable year. The term 'United States risk' refers to hazards, losses, or liabilities related to activities or property in the United States or its territories. Premiums and losses from risks covered by a catastrophe reserve in Puerto Rico are excluded from consideration when determining qualified contributions or losses. The IRS regulations specify that contributions in kind to a fund are treated as a sale or exchange of property at fair market value. Distributions in kind to a qualified insurance company are also treated as a sale or exchange, with any resulting gain or loss excluded from the company's gross income. The Secretary is authorized to issue further regulations on these matters. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for the purposes of this subsection. An additional tax on certain distributions from a Natural Disaster Protection Fund is imposed on qualified insurance companies. The tax is increased by 20 percent of nonqualified distributions made from the fund during the year. Definitions are provided for clarity. The bill defines nonqualified distributions as any distribution from a natural disaster protection fund that is not a qualified distribution. The terms 'qualified insurance company' and 'natural disaster protection fund' are also defined. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011.
